One rule that you can apply here is that in an ion, the oxidation number should equal to the charge of the ion. Sulfate's (SO4) charge is -2, so Zn must equal +2 to receive an overall ZnSO4 charge of zero (0). Hope that helps anyone having the same issue here.

It's Because SO4 is a Polyatomic Ion with an overall charge of -2. This leaves Zn which must have a +2 Charge in order for the Redox Rxn to balance. Be sure to remember your Polyatomic Ions & their charges to make this easier.

Carlos Auza Most important thing is that you caught the mistake yourself! That way, you'll be much more likely to catch it on an exam ! :-)
LKDbass Yes it can! Especially when you are looking at three or four reactants!

christian underwood You usually begin with a reference element, an element whose oxidation number is always (or almost always) the same. For example, we know that fluoride is always -1, so in a compound that contains fluoride, we would begin with fluoride. For oxygen, we know its almost always -2, so we would start with that, and so on.
Cherise Patterson Good to hear this cleared up your confusion! :-) I am sure you were not the only one who was confused though!

Hi Kate! Unfortunately, the only way to know the reactions is to memorize them! Once you do them enough times, you're going to get some intuition on what goes on the products side for the given reactants.
Hi! Well SO4 has a charge of -2 (something you just have to remember), so that implies that Zinc should have a charge of +2 because the entire molecule has an overall charge of zero.
